captions.text: HANK: Good morning, John!

I live in a city that most people would call
a small town. Missoula, Montana has 70,000

people in it when the students are here, and
when they leave for the summer, the population

declines significantly. Somehow, 70,000 people
is considered to be a small number of people.

It actually is quite a large number of people,
but, I mean, after all there are some cities

that have stadiums that hold more than 70,000
people, so.

For some perspective, Missoula packs those
70,000 people into 2600 square miles. Manhattan

has 22 times more people in 78 times less
area. And, of course, there are many amazing

things going on in Manhattan. It isn't just
1.3 million people. It's 1.3 million of the

richest, most powerful, most influential people
on the planet. Economic and cultural creation
on the scale of Renaissance Italy.

And that is an interesting comparison because
Florence in 1500 contained some of the most

powerful economic and cultural forces the
world has ever known. The Medici bankers,

Botticelli, Machiavelli, Michaelangelo, da
Vinci, Brunelleschi. It revolutionized the

world from the seat of the Renaissance in
Florence, Italy.

And what was the population of Florence, Italy?
1.3 million people? No. No millions of people!

No hundreds of thousands of people! 70,000.
Of course there were tremendous political

and economic and cultural and historic forces
that made Florence the seat of the Renaissance.

But one thing that I believe very deeply in
my heart, and I think most historians would

agree with me, is that it didn't happen because
there was just some random collection of really

great people. Great people are everywhere
all the time. It just so happens that only

occasionally our cultural and historical and
economic forces, such that they will be remembered
for hundreds or even thousands of years.

So I like to think of Missoula as like a little
Florence. And everyone walking around is an

unnoticed da Vinci and an unmade Machiavelli.
And I think about what separates the great

people that I remember from the great people
that everyone remembers. I think it's 100%
circumstance.

We're launching a new channel this week with
Jessi Knudsen Castañeda and her husband Augusto,

who you may know from their frequent appearances
on SciShow. They bring to us animals that

they have rescued so that we can talk about
them and educate the world. That's Jessi's
passion! That's her superpower.

And Caitlin Hoffmeister, who's also the producer
of SciShow, is going to be documenting the

passion, and sweat, and toil that it takes
to run a small business and feed hundreds

of mouths. Two of those mouths happen to be
twin infant children.

Now that I've produced shows with a bunch
of different interesting people here in Missoula--Emily

Graslie, and Lindsey Doe, and now Jessi--people
have asked me why are there so many interesting

things going on in this one little small town
in Missoula? That's the thing, though! That's

the point! There's interetsting things happening
everywhere!

This isn't a magical place and they're not
magical people. It's just people who have

found something that they're passionate about.
But yeah, that can be a hard thing to come

by. I've watched everyone I've ever known
struggle with that. Trying to find something
that they believe is important.

And I'm so grateful--changing topics here,
really fast--that Nerdfighteria has provided

that for me. People talk about all the things
that I've been able to do. But it is only

because I found something here that I can
believe in. Because, yeah, I live in Missoula,

Montana, but my first allegiance is to this
place.

A community of hundreds of thousands of people
with shared ideas, and values and interests.

Bigger than Missoula and thus even more full
of unappreciated and unnoticed da Vincis and

Machiavellis and Brunelleschis. The only difference
between something being vitally important,

and not important at all, is whether or not
you believe it is.

I believe that this is important, and that
is a gift that you have given me. Thank you!

John, your life seems like a bit of a grapefruit
right now. Don't freak out. Uhh, stay sane.
And I'll see you on Tuesday.

If you want to check out Jessi's new channel,
there's a link in the description. And there's

also you can just click over here if you're
not on your phone, you can click with your

mouse. But not with your phone, it doesn't
work on phones. Boop.

comments.author: SusanBailey AmazingEstate

comments.text:
I think what gives those historical figures their "greatness" isn't/wasn't 
necessarily their passion or their expertise or even their works. I don't 
think that "greatness" is a myth, really. I don't buy that there are a few 
handfuls of individuals that history remembers purely by 
chance/circumstance. I think "greatness" in the "being remembered by 
history" sense comes from leading a life that affects so many other people 
that culture takes notice of it. I think of the world like a pond, every 
action (and some cases of inaction) a person takes causes a ripple that 
affects everyone else to some degree eventually. Some people make a huge 
terrific great wave of a splash that changes the whole composition of the 
body itself, or simply a series of larger ripples that go on long enough to 
accomplish the same feat. Those are the lives we remember because they had 
such impact, not because they were more "interesting" or "passionate" than 
any other person. Maybe it could have been anybody to invent the telephone, 
but it was Bell. Maybe it could have been anyone to travel around the globe 
in one continuous voyage, but it was Magellan. It could have been anyone to 
conquer Asia, leaving countless bloodshed and *ahem* descendants in his 
wake, but it was Ghengis Khan.

To be clear, I'm not advocating the "Great Person" view of history, which 
is obviously wrong just by way of being too broad and not subtle in any 
way, shape, or form, I'm just trying to point out that you can't really 
deny that the people we do remember have a larger than average effect on a 
huge number of people. So it's not like those people are in some way 
greater than anyone else, but it's more like they were great to more 
people.﻿

comments.author: Aidan Clark

comments.text:
1.3 million people in manhattan out of 7 billion humans on Earth ~ 0.0186%
70 thousand people in Florence 1500 out of 500 million humans on Earth ~ 
0.014%

That's about equivalent, it represents the same proportion of humanity. If 
you strip numbers out of their context you can make them say anything you 
want. Yes 1.3 million is a far greater number than 70 thousand, but the 
meaning of it largely depends on the context.

And there I only took the number of people inhabiting the cities but is 
that really representative? What if we used instead the number of people 
that could read?
What's the proportion of literate people living in Florence in 1500 out of 
all literate people in the world at that time? Same question with the 
literate people in manhatan compared to the world 2014?﻿

comments.text:
Not really related to this video but I've been seeing a lot lately about 
how the milenial generation is doomed and how they are all narcissistic and 
too involved with technology and how they are going to distroy america 
unless they see the error in our ways and make a change. I completely 
disagree with this, technology has blossomed in the last few decades and 
gave us many advantages that the baby boomers were not exposed to and with 
this comes change. Culture is changing and society is changing and this 
doesn't have to be a bad thing. Just because the milenials seek the 
acceptance of their peers through social networks doesn't mean that we are 
self indulgent narcissistic kids who won't be able to succeed. I would like 
to hear john and hanks opinion on the milinials and their strengths and 
weaknesses.﻿

comments.author: MissFotini

comments.text:
It's strange, the struggle to 'find a passion' seemed a little like trying 
to stumble onto gold.
It feels like I'm standing in a room filled with many objects waiting for 
one to 'jump out at me' or 'catch my interest' but your phrasing takes a 
far less passive stance where this search for direction is concerned and 
says I shouldn't stand in the room and wait for it to choose me but rather 
I should choose it. But even that isn't quite right because that just 
leaves you wondering by what mechanism you choose and you are back to 
square one waiting from something to jump out at you to help you choose.

So I like the idea in your video that you choose whether something is 
important or not because we assign value to things otherwise they will all 
always all have the same objective value of nil. I feel like it's an 
awfully fragile sort of thought but maybe choosing to make something your 
passion, and accepting that maybe it'll turn out not to be quite exactly 
your passion...is ok? Like the worst that could happen is that It'd give 
more form to something I can be passionate about.

Thank you, maybe none of that made sense but it's like in games when you've 
been misunderstanding a mechanic or a puzzle and it suddenly slides into 
place and a sensation of new options/areas/objects becoming available is 
experienced. ﻿

Hank, New York is the biggest financial center of the U.S. but it is 
overrated. Banking, stock market, and finance certainly make people 
wealthy, but all they are doing is circulating money, not creating wealth. 
The center of ideas (and wealth creation) is almost entirely on the west 
coast, starting with Silicon Valley. NY doesn't have a Silicon Valley or 
anything remotely close to it. ﻿
